title: EXCHANGE --- Heard on the Street: Overheard
text:
Amazon.com's new chief executive didn't appear on the company's second-quarter call Thursday afternoon. That continues a long tradition: Founder and former CEO Jeff Bezos hasn't participated in those calls since 2009, according to a transcript search on S&P Global Market Intelligence.

For Mr. Bezos, the habit seemed part of an intense time-management strategy. He admitted in an interview at Business Insider's Ignite conference in 2014 that he spends just six hours a year on investor relations, claiming that he meets only with long-term investors "with low portfolio turns."

Whether Mr. Jassy will be afforded the same luxury remains to be seen. He formally took over the CEO job on July 5 -- after the second quarter ended. But the first report under his watch still turned out to be a doozy, with Amazon's revenue and operating income missing Wall Street's targets and sending the stock tumbling.

Still, while running the company's cloud business, he did show at least one sign of being more out-front with investors by presenting at a Goldman Sachs conference early last year.

Mr. Jassy's equally busy peers at Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet and Facebook all participate in their quarterly calls. Amazon investors gave Mr. Bezos a pass, as the stock has returned more than 4,000% since he stopped appearing on the company's calls. Mr. Jassy might not get cut quite as much slack.
